en: Bodleian Library MS. Ind. Inst. Misc. 22
Bodleian Library MS. Ind. Inst. Misc. 22
Digitized Kalighat paintings from 19th century Calcutta, created as inexpensive souvenirs for Hindu pilgrims visiting the famous temple of Kali

These paintings were acquired by Sir Monier Monier-Williams for the Indian Institute Library and Museum at Oxford as a result of his third fund-raising trip to India in the winter of 1883-1884. During this trip, he secured the help of various regional authorities in obtaining local art and craft works and sending them to Oxford. The Kalighat paintings are listed in Babu T.N. Mukherji's "List of Articles collected for the Oxford Institute under the instruction of T.W. Holderness Esq. and Dr. George Watt," Calcutta, 1884, which is bound in the "Original Lists" MS. volume held in the Department of Eastern Art, Ashmolean Museum.The paintings are homogenous in style, resembling that of collections in documented ownership by about 1875: the India Office Library from the 1871 exhibition, the museums in Prague and St. Petersburg, the Herwitz batch A (1870) published by Jyotindra Jain and those acquired by the Victoria and Albert Museum in 1887. Some of the paintings originally had labels stuck to them, which indicated they had cost 1 anna each.
Waterbased colour on machine made paper over pencil, mounted on paper
Kalighat (Calcutta, India)--Social life and customs--Pictorial works--19th century
Access to this manuscript is restricted - please email for details
[f. 1 Krishna and his lover Radha seated face-to-face]
[f. 2 Cat (with Vaishnavite mark on forehead) with crayfish: perhaps represents a Bengali proverb or satire on religion]
[f. 5 A Peri, a fairy of Persian tradition]
[f. 7 Sepoys, soldiers of the Indian army]
[f. 8 The clerk Nabin Bannerji kills his unfaithful wife Elokeshi at Tarakeshwar, 27 May 1873]
[f. 11 A brahmin kneeling before two tigers - meaning uncertain]
[f. 15 Babu (dandy) out on the street, muskrats partying in his home: a social satire]
[f. 16 The clerk Nabin Bannerji kills his unfaithful wife Elokeshi at Tarakeshwar, 27 May 1873]
[f. 17 Bhima, a hero of the Mahabharata war, and Hirsimha]
[f. 18 Kamale-Kamini: a legend of Durga as Mangala Chandi]
[f. 20 Karttikeya, the god of war, son of Shiva and Lakshmi, riding the peacock Paravani]
[f. 21 A bhisti, water-carrier, of very low caste: possibly the Mahant (high priest) of Tarakeshwar, gaoled for his adultery with Elokeshi in 1872/3]
[f. 25 Carnival float for the Muslim holy day of Muharrram, in the form of Buraq, the beast on which Muhammad flew to heaven]
[f. 26 Muhammad's mount Duldul bearing a trophy, perhaps a carnival float for the Muslim holy day of Muharram]
[f. 28 Bird seated on head of old Brahmin: depicts Bengali expressions referring either to his mettle, despite his age, or to his ruin, if frivolous thoughts enter his head]
[f. 29 Lakshmi Bai, Rani (Queen) of Jhansi, a heroine of the Sepoy Mutiny, killed fighting the British, 1857]
[f. 30 Hand with three prawns, perhaps a Bengali proverb]
[f. 40 Woman holding rose to man transformed into a sheep]
[f. 72 Hanuman with Rama and Sita in his heart]
